p.text: The Commercial Arbitration Act 1984 No 160 was assented to 14 December 1984 and commenced 1 May 1985. It was repealed on 1 October 2010 by the Commercial Arbitration Act 2010 s 42. Prior to repeal, it was amended by the following instruments:

row.entry: s 4 and Sch 2: 25 November 1990 (Gaz 141 of 9 November 1990)
Building and Construction Industry Security of Payment Act 1999 No 46
Miscellaneous Acts (Local Court) Amendment Act 2007 No 94

p.text: An Act to make provision with respect to the arbitration of certain disputes and to repeal the Arbitration Act 1902 and the Arbitration (Foreign Awards and Agreements) Act 1973 , and for other purposes.
This Act may be cited as the Commercial Arbitration Act 1984.
Sections 1 and 2 shall commence on the date of assent to this Act.
Except as provided by subsection (1) , this Act shall commence on such day as may be appointed by the Governor in respect thereof and as may be notified by proclamation published in the Gazette.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [275,010] s 3 Repeal, transitional and application provisions

p.text: The Acts mentioned in Schedule 1 are repealed to the extent to which they are in that Schedule expressed to be repealed.
Subject to subsection (3) :
this Act applies to an arbitration agreement (whether made before or after the commencement of this Act) and to an arbitration under such an agreement, and
a reference in an arbitration agreement to the Arbitration Act 1902 , or a provision of that Act, shall be construed as a reference to this Act or to the corresponding provision (if any) of this Act.

Where an arbitration was commenced before the commencement of this Act, the law governing the arbitration and the arbitration agreement shall be that which would have been applicable if this Act had not been enacted.
[subs (3) am Act 100 of 1990 s 4 and Sch 2]
Subject to this section, this Act shall apply to arbitrations provided for in any other Act as if:
the other Act were an arbitration agreement,
the arbitration were pursuant to an arbitration agreement, and
the parties to the dispute which, by virtue of the other Act, is referred to arbitration were the parties to the arbitration agreement,
except in so far as the other Act otherwise indicates or requires.
For the purposes of this section, an arbitration shall be deemed to have been commenced if:
a dispute to which the relevant arbitration agreement applies has arisen, and
a party to the agreement:

has served on another party to the agreement a notice requiring that other party to appoint an arbitrator or to join or concur in or approve of the appointment of an arbitrator in relation to the dispute,
has served on another party to the agreement a notice requiring that other party to refer, or to concur in the reference of, the dispute to arbitration, or

has taken any other step contemplated by the agreement, or the law in force at the time the dispute arose, with a view to referring the dispute to arbitration or appointing, or securing the appointment of, an arbitrator in relation to the dispute.
Nothing in this Act applies to:

an arbitration under the Supreme Court Act 1970 , the District Court Act 1973 or Part 5 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005 (except to the extent that those Acts expressly provide for the application of this Act), or
an arbitration, or class of arbitrations, prescribed as an arbitration, or class of arbitrations, to which this Act does not apply.
[subs (6) subst Act 100 of 1990 s 4 and Sch 2; am Act No 28 of 2005 s 5.6 and Sch 5, effective 15 August 2005]
Nothing in this Act shall affect the operation of section 19 of the Insurance Act 1902, or section 130 of the Credit Act 1984.
Nothing in this Act affects the operation of Part 3 of the Building and Construction Industry Security of Payment Act 1999.
[subs (8) am Act 46 of 1999 s 36 and Sch 1]
In this Act, except in so far as the context or subject-matter otherwise indicates or requires:
means an agreement in writing to refer present or future disputes to arbitration.
in relation to costs, means assess under Division 11 of Part 3.2 of the Legal Profession Act 2004.
[def insrt Act 68 of 2004 s 3 and Sch 2 , effective 6 July 2004 ; am Act No 46 of 2005 s 5 and Sch 11, effective 1 October 2005]
means final or interim award.
[def rep Act 100 of 1990 s 4 and Sch 2]
includes corruption, fraud, partiality, bias and a breach of the rules of natural justice.
, in relation to an arbitration agreement, includes any person claiming through or under a party to the arbitration agreement.

deflist.defitem:
power of appointment or power to appoint
, in relation to an arbitrator or umpire, means a power to appoint an arbitrator or umpire, to join in the appointment of an arbitrator or umpire, to concur in or approve of the appointment of an arbitrator or umpire, or to take any other step in or towards the appointment of an arbitrator or umpire.

p.text: [def rep Act 100 of 1990 s 4 and Sch 2]
means, subject to subsection (2) , the Supreme Court.
Where:
an arbitration agreement provides that the District Court or the Local Court shall have jurisdiction under this Act, or
the parties to an arbitration agreement have agreed in writing that the District Court or the Local Court shall have jurisdiction under this Act and that agreement is in force,
a reference in this Act to the Court is, in relation to that agreement, a reference to the District Court or the Local Court, as the case requires.
[subs (2) am Act No 28 of 2005 s 5.4 and Sch 5, effective 15 August 2005 ; Act 94 of 2007 s 4 and Sch 2, effective 6 July 2009]
A reference in this Act to an arbitrator includes, in a case where there are 2 or more arbitrators, a reference to the arbitrators.
[subs (3) subst Act 100 of 1990 s 3 and Sch 1]
Legislation cited in [275,015.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Commercial Arbitration Act 1984 [275,445].

The statutory definition should be given a wide scope consistent with the brevity of its terms and the scope of the legislation: PMT Partners Pty Ltd (in liq) v Australian National Parks & Wildlife Service (1995) 184 CLR 301; 131 ALR 377 . An agreement which confers a unilateral right to refer disputes is an arbitration agreement for the purposes of this section: Pittalis v Sherefettin [1986] QB 868; [1986] 2 All ER 227 ; Turner Corp Ltd v Austotel Pty Ltd (1992) 27 NSWLR 592 . An agreement which makes the obligation, or entitlement, to refer contingent on the happening of a particular event, is also an arbitration agreement: Savcor Pty Ltd v New South Wales (2001) 52 NSWLR 587; [2001] NSWSC 596; BC200103967 (right to refer conditional on prior expert determination and monetary threshold). See further [275,445] .
Legislation cited in [275,015.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Commercial Arbitration Act 1984 [275,445].

Commercial agreements to refer disputes to arbitration should not be construed narrowly. An agreement to refer disputes "arising out of the contract" includes disputes arising out of representations and misleading conduct occurring during the course of the contract: Francis Travel Marketing Pty Ltd v Virgin Atlantic Airways Ltd (1996) 39 NSWLR 160 at 165; 131 FLR 422 . Similarly, an agreement to refer to arbitration any disputes "concerning this agreement" includes a claim based on unjust enrichment: O'Connor v Leaw Pty Ltd (1997) 42 NSWLR 285; BC9703387 . An arbitration agreement constitutes a separate contract enabling the arbitrator to deal with the whole dispute, not merely those aspects which arise out of the contract itself: Ferris v Plaister (1994) 34 NSWLR 474 . See also an article by Justice Giles: "Severability of Dispute Resolution Clauses in Contracts", Building and Construction Law , Vol 10, no 6, 1994, p 393; see also [275,445] .

level.toc-caption: [275,015.15] Characterisation of the agreement – arbitration or expert determination

heading.title: Characterisation of the agreement – arbitration or expert determination

p.text: An arbitrator must be impartial, must decide according to the substantive law: Techno-Impex v Gebr Van Weelde [1981] QB 648 per Oliver LJ at 669 and Watkins LJ at 680 ) and must decide on the basis of the competing submissions of the parties, unless the nature of the dispute renders this requirement inappropriate: Arenson v Casson Beckman Rutley & Co [1977] AC 405; [1975] 3 All ER 901 ). An expert is not so confined.

There is no specific criterion for characterising a particular agreement as providing for arbitration as distinct from expert determination: Arenson v Casson Beckman Rutley & Co [1977] AC 405 at 427; [1975] 3 All ER 901 per Lord Wheatley. Consequently, it is often difficult to distinguish between an arbitration agreement and an agreement providing for expert determination — see Ajzner v Cartonlux Pty Ltd [1972] VR 919 ; Re Dawdy & Hartcup (1885) 15 QBD 426 at 430 per Lord Esher; Badgin Nominees Pty Ltd v Oneida Ltd [1998] VSC 188; BC9807200 (referral to a chartered accountant to determine as an expert); AMP Society v OTC (Aust) [1972] NSWLR 806 at 813, 818 . Factors relevant to the distinction include the terms of the agreement and its subject matter: Edmund Barton Chambers (Level 44) Co-op Ltd v MLC Assurance Co Ltd (1984) NSW ConvR ¶55-177 at 57,256; BC8400354 ; Thomas Cook Pty Ltd v Commonwealth Banking Corp (1986) 4 BPR 9185; (1986) ANZ ConvR 598 . The use of the description of either "abritrator" or "expert" may point towards the true characterisation of the referral procedure: Edmund Barton Chambers (Level 44) Co-op Ltd v MLC Assurance Co Ltd (1984) NSW ConvR ¶55-177 at 57,256; BC8400354 ; but it is not conclusive: Taylor v Yielding (1912) 56 Sol Jo 253 ; IOOF Australia Trustees Ltd v SEAS Sapfor Forests Pty Ltd (SASC, Debelle J, 3 November 1995, unreported, BC9502399) . The fact that the agreement provides for the determination of a "dispute" is one indication suggesting the parties intended arbitration: Arenson v Casson Beckman Rutley & Co [1977] AC 405 at 424; [1975] 3 All ER 901 per Lord Simon; Alliance Petroleum Australia NL v Australian Gas Light Co (1983) 34 SASR 215; 48 ALR 69 . On the other hand, if the agreement specifies particular qualifications required of the proposed referee, they may tend to indicate that expert determination was intended: Edmund Barton Chambers (Level 44) Co-op Ltd v MLC Assurance Co Ltd (1984) NSW ConvR ¶55-177; BC8400354 .
Where the Crown (whether in right of the State of New South Wales or in any other capacity) is a party to an arbitration agreement, the Crown is bound by this Act.
[s 5 am Act 100 of 1990 s 4 and Sch 2]
